items.title: SyntaxError: invalid syntax -- baseTime = min(time * (1L << retries), cap);
items.body:
python 3.6.2

importing 
```
from snakebite.client import Client
```

results in
```
  File "<input>", line 1, in <module>
    from snakebite.client import Client
  File "/***********/lib/python3.6/site-packages/snakebite/client.py", line 1473
    baseTime = min(time * (1L << retries), cap);
                            ^
SyntaxError: invalid syntax
```

It is the same issue as in https://github.com/spotify/snakebite/issues/216

Providing a Python 3 package is misleading, and should be removed from pypi if does not work.

items.title: get_external_config seems not to read config from $HADOOP_HOME/etc
items.body:
In the source code here:
https://github.com/spotify/snakebite/blob/6a456e6100b0c1be66cc1f7f9d7f50494f369da3/snakebite/config.py#L133

`get_external_conf` actually doesn't read `core-site.xml` or `hdfs-site.xml` from `$HADOOP_HOME/etc`.

But in `hdfs_try_paths` [here](https://github.com/spotify/snakebite/blob/master/snakebite/commandlineparser.py#L300), snakebite says it tried.

items.title: snakebite.errors.RequestError: javax.security.sasl.SaslException Client mechanism is malformed
items.body:
Related-To: https://github.com/spotify/snakebite/issues/175

I am trying to get snakebite to work (for Airflow) in a container environment and having a few issues.  I removed Airflow (target client) from the picture and created this basic script to test things out

```
$ cat check_snakebite.py
from snakebite.client import Client, AutoConfigClient, HAClient, Namenode

c = HAClient([Namenode('host1', 8020), Namenode('host2', 8020)],
        hdfs_namenode_principal='hdfs/_HOST@EXAMPLE.COM',
        effective_user='user/not.real.hostname@EXAMPLE.COM',
        use_sasl=True)

for x in c.ls(['/']):
  print x
```

I have two clusters I am testing out; a hadoop cluster I created, and one created by CDH.  When I run the above script on a physical node (host portion of principle matches hostname), it works just fine against my test cluster.  When I move the script into a docker container and call the CDH cluster, I get the below exception.  Since this is in Docker, the hostname doesn't match principle (nor do I have permissions to fix the hostname).

From the same host, using the hadoop libraries work fine, and so does code we have written in java. Its only when I try to use snakebite that this fails.

Thanks for your time reading this issue

```
bash-4.3$ python check_snakebite.py
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "check_snakebite.py", line 8, in <module>
    for x in c.ls(['/']):
  File "/python/lib/python2.7/site-packages/snakebite/client.py", line 1542, in wrapped
    self.__handle_request_error(e)
  File "/python/lib/python2.7/site-packages/snakebite/client.py", line 1540, in wrapped
    yield results.next()
  File "/python/lib/python2.7/site-packages/snakebite/client.py", line 168, in ls
    recurse=recurse):
  File "/python/lib/python2.7/site-packages/snakebite/client.py", line 1214, in _find_items
    fileinfo = self._get_file_info(path)
  File "/python/lib/python2.7/site-packages/snakebite/client.py", line 1342, in _get_file_info
    return self.service.getFileInfo(request)
  File "/python/lib/python2.7/site-packages/snakebite/service.py", line 40, in <lambda>
    rpc = lambda request, service=self, method=method.name: service.call(service_stub_class.__dict__[method], request)
  File "/python/lib/python2.7/site-packages/snakebite/service.py", line 46, in call
    return method(self.service, controller, request)
  File "/python/lib/python2.7/site-packages/google/protobuf/service_reflection.py", line 267, in <lambda>
    self._StubMethod(inst, method, rpc_controller, request, callback))
  File "/python/lib/python2.7/site-packages/google/protobuf/service_reflection.py", line 284, in _StubMethod
    method_descriptor.output_type._concrete_class, callback)

    sasl_connected = sasl.connect()
  File "/python/lib/python2.7/site-packages/snakebite/rpc_sasl.py", line 98, in connect
    res = self._recv_sasl_message()
  File "/python/lib/python2.7/site-packages/snakebite/rpc_sasl.py", line 79, in _recv_sasl_message

  File "/python/lib/python2.7/site-packages/snakebite/channel.py", line 421, in handle_error
```

items.title: does snakebite support connecting through hadoop ha proxy host
items.body:
**core-hdfs.xml**
```
    <property>
      <name>fs.defaultFS</name>
      <value>hdfs://mycluster</value>
    </property>
```



**hdfs-site.xml** 
```
 <property>
      <name>dfs.ha.namenodes.mycluster</name>
      <value>nn1,nn2</value>
    </property>
```

above is the name node high available configuration,
can i use below code?
```
from snakebite.client import Client
client = Client("mycluster")
```

items.title: Invalid syntax and module error
items.body:
Installed snakebite-2.11.0 under CentOS 7 and Fedora 24.  Both return an invalid syntax and a module exception:

```
  File "/usr/lib/python3.4/site-packages/snakebite-2.11.0-py3.4.egg/snakebite/client.py", line 1473
    baseTime = min(time * (1L << retries), cap);
                            ^
SyntaxError: invalid syntax
```

Once we fixed this, a module exception is thrown:

```
  File "/usr/lib/python3.5/site-packages/snakebite/client.py", line 16, in <module>
    import snakebite.protobuf.ClientNamenodeProtocol_pb2 as client_proto
  File "/usr/lib/python3.5/site-packages/snakebite/protobuf/ClientNamenodeProtocol_pb2.py", line 12, in <module>
    import Security_pb2
ImportError: No module named 'Security_pb2'
```

items.title: Possible bug : Methods work only with print
items.body:
I am using the snakebite client and i notice a strange behavior when i try to make a directory or move files around in hdfs. Here is my code. All it does it move the contents of the source directory to the destination directory. Then finally, displays the content of the destination directory

```
def purge_pending(self,source_dir,dest_dir):

        if(self.hdfs_serpent.test(path=self.root_dir+"/"+source_dir, exists=True, directory=True)):
            print "Source exists ",self.root_dir+source_dir
            for x in self.hdfs_serpent.ls([self.root_dir+source_dir]):
                print x['path']
        else:
            print "Source does not exist ",self.root_dir+"/"+source_dir
            return
        if(self.hdfs_serpent.test(path=self.root_dir+"/"+dest_dir, exists=True, directory=True)):
            print "Destination exists ",self.root_dir+dest_dir
        else:
            print "Destination does not exist ",self.root_dir+dest_dir
            print "Will be created"
            for y in self.hdfs_serpent.mkdir([self.root_dir+dest_dir],create_parent=True):
                print y

        for src in self.hdfs_serpent.ls([self.root_dir+source_dir]):
            print src['path'].split("/")[-1]
            for y in self.hdfs_serpent.rename([src['path']],self.root_dir+dest_dir+"/"+src['path'].split("/")[-1]):
                print y


        for x in self.hdfs_serpent.ls([self.root_dir+dest_dir]):
            print x['path']
```

and here is a sample output from when the destination did not exist

```
Source exists  /root/source
/root/source/208560.json
/root/source/208571.json
/root/source/208574.json
/root/source/208581.json
/root/source/208707.json
Destination does not exist /root/dest
Will be created
{'path':'/research/dest/'}
208560.json
{'path':'/research/dest/208560.json'}
208571.json
{'path':'/research/dest/208571.json'}
208574.json
{'path':'/research/dest/208574.json'}
208581.json
{'path':'/research/dest/208581.json'}
208707.json
{'path':'/research/dest/208707.json'}
```

and the weird part is that i have to put those print statements in, otherwise nothing works. So 

```
self.hdfs_serpent.mkdir([self.root_dir+dest_dir],create_parent=True)
```

does not work, but 

```
for y in self.hdfs_serpent.mkdir([self.root_dir+dest_dir],create_parent=True):
                print y
```

does!!! same for 

```
self.hdfs_serpent.rename([src['path']],self.root_dir+dest_dir+"/"+src['path'].split("/")[-1])
```

as the above does not work but the following does

```
for y in self.hdfs_serpent.rename([src['path']],self.root_dir+dest_dir+"/"+src['path'].split("/")[-1]):
                print y
```

is this a bug? am i doing something wrong?

items.title: Question: Why does README specify to install version 1.3.x?

items.title: IWBN to retry after namenode failures
items.body:
Hello,
When snakebite queries all known namenode servers, and they fail, we get errors like:

INFO:  File "... /snakebite/client.py", line 1392, in wrapped
INFO:    self.__handle_request_error(e)
INFO:  File " ... /snakebite/client.py", line 1370, in __handle_request_error
INFO:    self.namenode.next()
INFO:  File " ... /snakebite/client.py", line 1361, in _switch_namenode
INFO:    raise OutOfNNException(msg)
INFO:OutOfNNException: Request tried and failed for all 2 namenodes:
INFO:                  \* ...-namenode-...
INFO:                  \* ...-namenode-....

It would be great if snakebite could retry after errors like this, instead of failing.  One possibility would be to exponentially increase retry times, up to some limit of retries or time.

Thank you,
- Jim

items.title: Support for CHECKSUM_NULL
items.body:
Hi,

Please add support for CHECKSUM_NULL.

Easy two line fix in channel.py

```
# diff channel.py channel.py.orig
577,579c577
<         if checksum_type in [self.CHECKSUM_NULL]:
<             checksum_len = 0
<         elif checksum_type in [self.CHECKSUM_CRC32C, self.CHECKSUM_CRC32]:

---
>         if checksum_type in [self.CHECKSUM_CRC32C, self.CHECKSUM_CRC32]:
```

Should probably also add logic to ignore the --checkcrc option if the checksum is non/null.

Thanks,
Chris

I hit a krb5.h error when pip install. It looks like there is a hard dependency on the python-krbV library. Is this absolutely required for snakebite to work? In the spotify blog post, it advertises itself as a a pure Python HDFS client.

Anyway, I commented out any references to sasl and kerberos. Snakebite seems to work this way.

items.title: Kerberos principal hardwired
items.body:
Hello,
we have faced issues connecting to our Hadoop cluster with snakebite. Finally, we found out that in snakebite the name node's kerberos principal is hardwired to be "hdfs" -- see the connect()-method in snakebite.rpc_sasl.SaslRpcClient, where the attribute "service" is set to "hdfs". Changing "hdfs" to the name of our kerberos principal resolved our issues.

The way it looks to me is that snakebite only evaluates hdfs-site.xml in order to obtain the name node's address and port and to find out if the cluster runs in secure mode by checking whether the property hadoop.security.authentication has the value "kerberos". I guess the way it "should" be is that the kerberos principal configured by the property dfs.namenode.kerberos.principal 
should be used to set the kerberos principal rather than hardwiring it to "hdfs". In other words, the kerberos principal's name obtained from that setting should be passed to snakebite.rpc_sasl.SaslRpcClient and used in its connect()-method to set the attribute "service" accordingly.

Best regards,
Stefan

items.title: Library not compatible with Windows
items.body:
I'm using Python 2.7.10 on Windows 7. I installed snakebite using the version of Pip that's bundled with the Python 2.7 Windows installer (ie. `pip install snakebite`).

When I then try to make use of snakebite as an HDFS client, I get a stack trace on import:

```
C:\Python27>python
Python 2.7.10 (default, May 23 2015, 09:44:00) [MSC v.1500 64 bit (AMD64)] on win32
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> from snakebite.client import HAClient
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\snakebite\client.py", line 19, in <module>
    from snakebite.service import RpcService
  File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\snakebite\service.py", line 16, in <module>
    from snakebite.channel import SocketRpcChannel
  File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\snakebite\channel.py", line 44, in <module>
    import pwd
ImportError: No module named pwd
```

I may be doing something obviously wrong here, so my apologies if this isn't a real issue. If this is a known problem, I'd be interested in trying to put together a pull request to fix it. Thanks!

items.title: HADOOP_HOME is deprecated.
items.body:
Hello!

I was trying out snakebite on my hadoop cluster and it seems that snakebite still uses HADOOP_HOME environment variable to check things. To my knowledge, this had been deprecated lately and most new users will not have this in their config files.

I can write a patch and submit a PR that can fix this to check on HADOOP_INSTALL or HADOOP_PREFIX (both in most cases point to the same path, usually /usr/local/hadoop)

items.title: Docs on http://snakebite.readthedocs.org/
items.body:
I added building docs on http://snakebite.readthedocs.org/, which is automatically done on commit instead of manually running scripts/release.sh (which isn't very safe). 
Should we move to readthedocs.org completely?

items.title: Support fully qualified URIs
items.body:
Currently fully qualified HDFS URIs are not supported. E.g:

```
client.ls(['hdfs://nnAddress:nnPort/path'])
```

will result in `org.apache.hadoop.fs.InvalidPathException`, because normalizations that happen [here](https://github.com/spotify/snakebite/blob/master/snakebite/client.py#L1147) and [here](https://github.com/spotify/snakebite/blob/master/snakebite/client.py#L1151) will produce an invalid path like this:

```
/user/someuser/hdfs:/nnAddress:nnPort/path
```

Two seemingly straight-forward solutions to enhance current state would be to:
1. detect fully qualified path early on and throw a more obvious `not supported exception`
2. detect fully qualified path early on and remove the prefix so that **snakebite** can carry on as usual

items.title: Methods for writing data not implemented?
items.body: It appears that the client doesn't have methods like `put` or `appendToFile`, and the documentation doesn't make it clear whether this is possible. Is there a way to write files to HDFS using snakebite? If not, are there plan to implement that?

items.title: Wrong default port in the documentation example
items.body:
Hello,

I tried to use Snakebite as a library in the single node Cloudera VM. In order to do that,  I followed the example bellow :

``` python
from snakebite.client import Client
client = Client("localhost", 54310, use_trash=False)
for x in client.ls(['/']):
    print x
```

Example grabbed from here https://spotify.github.io/snakebite/client.html

This example doesn't work while the command line tools works very well. So I checked at your code (https://github.com/spotify/snakebite/blob/master/snakebite/namenode.py) and see the following line : 

``` python
DEFAULT_PORT = 8020
```

I tried this value of port : and it work very well... so in order to not make other people confuse, I recommend to change the default port value of this example in your documentation, which it is not coherent with the Snakebite command line tools default value. That will save time of people who begin with your wonderful library ;-)

Thanks in advance,

items.title: copyToLocal assumes common prefix for all source paths
items.body:
Discovered during investigation of #134 - in `_handle_copyToLocal` there's optimization to compute common prefix for source only from first input path:

```
if self.base_source is None:
  self.dst = os.path.abspath(dst)
  if os.path.isdir(dst):  # If input destination is an existing directory, include toplevel
    self.base_source = os.path.dirname(path)
  else:
    self.base_source = path
```

This will store "common" prefix for source paths  - but in source files are in different parent directories this results in error.

Try to: `snakebite copyToLocal /user/foo/a /user/bar/c /home/foobar` this will copy `a` to foobar home directory but operation will fail for `c`. Solution could be to compute prefix for each input path.

Premature optimization is the root of all evil.

items.title: copyToLocal trying to write to / regardless of dst
items.body:
Given a list of source files like so
['/rawdata/date_id=20150127/datacenter_id=CHCM/file.dat',
 '/rawdata/date_id=20150127/datacenter_id=CHCM/file2.dat',
 '/rawdata/date_id=20150127/datacenter_id=CHCM/file3.dat',
 '/rawdata/date_id=20150127/datacenter_id=CHCM/file4.dat',
 '/rawdata/date_id=20150127/datacenter_id=CHCM/file5.dat']

and an output dir like so
'/data/CHCM_20150127/files'

copyToLocal(source, dst) is trying to write the returned files to root "/"

    entry = processor(full_path, fileinfo.fs)
  File "/opt/grab/lib/python2.7/site-packages/snakebite/client.py", line 703, in <lambda>

items.title: Latest CDH tarball (5.3.0) breaks df unit tests
items.body:
For CDH tests we fetch the latest CDH 5 distribution from:

```
http://archive.cloudera.com/cdh5/cdh/5/hadoop-latest.tar.gz
```

It was updates on 2014-12-21, and now unit tests for `df` operation fail.

Truncated output from tests:

```
Using cdh distribution of Hadoop from /tmp/hadoop-cdh
test_invalid_input (test.du_test.DfTest) ... ok
test_multipath (test.du_test.DfTest) ... ERROR
test_onepath (test.du_test.DfTest) ... ERROR
test_toplevel (test.du_test.DfTest) ... ERROR
test_unknown_file (test.du_test.DfTest) ... ok
```

The error:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/rav/projects/snakebite/test/du_test.py", line 30, in test_multipath
    expected_output = sorted(self.cluster.du(['/', '/dir1']), key=lambda node: node['path'])
  File "/Users/rav/projects/snakebite/snakebite/minicluster.py", line 117, in du
    return self._transform_du_output(self._runCmd([self._hadoop_cmd, 'fs', '-du'] + extra_args + src), self.hdfs_url)
  File "/Users/rav/projects/snakebite/snakebite/minicluster.py", line 205, in _transform_du_output
    (length, path) = re.split("\s+", line)
ValueError: too many values to unpack
```

It's possible that output syntax from `hadoop fs -du` command changed - still requires validation.

items.title: Snakebite 'test' returns a string instead of the return code
items.body:
both 'test' (the unix command) and the default hdfs test program follow the convention that an existence test either returns 0 if the test passes or non-zero if it fails.

Snakebite breaks this convention by returning a string 'XXX: No such file or directory' when a test fails. This could possibly cause breakage in scripts if making assumptions about test's behavior.

items.title: Snakebite unable to parse core-site.xml in EMR

milestone.title: v2.5.0
milestone.description:
Minor release with:
* support for EMR
* rename2 logic

items.body:
When snakebite attempts to read core-site.xml file on EMR, it is looking for the property name 'fs.defaultFS' for the name of the master node. But in EMR clusters, that property is under the name 'fs.default.name'. To accomodate this, config.py should attempt to search for this value name if the first value search returns null.

Excerpt from the core-site.xml file from EMR:

```
<?xml version="1.0"?>
<?xml-stylesheet type="text/xsl" href="configuration.xsl"?>
<configuration>
  <property><name>hadoop.proxyuser.hadoop.groups</name><value>*</value></property>
  <property><name>fs.s3n.impl</name><value>com.amazon.ws.emr.hadoop.fs.EmrFileSystem</value></property>
  <property><name>fs.s3.impl</name><value>com.amazon.ws.emr.hadoop.fs.EmrFileSystem</value></property>
  <property><name>fs.default.name</name><value>masterNodeName</value></property>....
```

items.title: Snakebite touchz only cares about first file
items.body:
This both affects the cli (`snakebite touchz path_1 path_2`) and the internal implementation in `snakebite/client.py:Client.touchz()`. 

```
~ arash@lon4-edgenode-b5  
❯ snakebite mkdir arash-test
OK: /user/arash/arash-test

~ arash@lon4-edgenode-b5  
❯ snakebite ls arash-test
Found 0 items

~ arash@lon4-edgenode-b5  
❯ snakebite touchz arash-test/a arash-test/b
OK: /user/arash/arash-test/a

~ arash@lon4-edgenode-b5  
❯ snakebite ls arash-test
Found 1 items
-rw-r--r--   3 arash      hadoop              0 2014-12-03 17:33 /user/arash/arash-test/a
```

@ravwojdyla, I suppose this won't get fixed fast right (unless I do it myself :))? I'll just make a work around for myself. :)

items.title: Copy is not implemented?
items.body: It seems copy functionality is missing. Is that right?

items.title: Fix constant failures of travis ci
items.body: Travis is constantly failing for test_cat_file_on_3_blocks test. Investigate why and find solution so that we can depend on travis again.

items.title: Unexpected end-group tag.
items.body:
/root/portal/lib/python2.7/site-packages/google/protobuf/internal/python_message.pyc in MergeFromString(self, serialized)
    842         # The only reason _InternalParse would return early is if it
    843         # encountered an end-group tag.
--> 844         raise message_mod.DecodeError('Unexpected end-group tag.')
    845     except (IndexError, TypeError):
    846       # Now ord(buf[p:p+1]) == ord('') gets TypeError.

items.title: Snakebite ls .. produces unexpected output
Add release script to automate release process
Update Tox to Tox 1.8
items.body:
Currently out tox.ini has a lot of duplication including basepython and some environmental variables. Unfortunately there's no better solution for that in 1.7.x
One of the features in Tox 1.8 is "multi-dimensional configuration support" - sounds awesome indeed!
Documentation -> http://tox.readthedocs.org/en/latest/changelog.html#dev1
Currently there's developer preview of version 1.8 and afaiu multi-dimensional configuration should reduce code and increase readability of tox.ini. So as soon as it's available let's use it!

items.title: Update documentation about testing via Fig
Update documentation about testing via Tox
Absolute data_files path breaks virtualenv
items.body:
The commit at https://github.com/spotify/snakebite/commit/ab11f9dabaf7263b626ba43274c68149d1c5ebb0#diff-2eeaed663bd0d25b7e608891384b7298
changed the data_files path for the etc bash_completion script to an absolute /etc path, which makes snakebite fail to install in a virtualenv/non-root environment

copying scripts/snakebite-completion.bash -> /etc/bash_completion.d

error: /etc/bash_completion.d/snakebite-completion.bash: Permission denied

items.title: Use Fig to make testing totally isolated
items.body: With Tox we isolated python environments and enhance testing process, which is cool, but tests still run on developers machines, that has to provide java and hadoop distribution. With Fig we should be able to abstract away operation system using docker and provide testing images so that testing is totally isolated and the same everywhere (in "perfect" world).

items.title: Travis should use java7
items.body: Java 7 is recommended for Hadoop 2.x.

items.title: data_files not included in sdist
items.body:
In py2.6 and still in 2.7 sdist may not include data_files from setup.py in source distribution which make some file unreachable during install process (including bash completion and license file).

@wouterdebie how do you produce tarballs available in pypi, I can see they have license and bash completion but I can't reproduce this via `python setup.py sdist`?

To solve the problem, let's add MANIFEST.in and add all required files including:
- bash completion
- license

Also since by default sdist includes all test/test\* files, which at the moment includes two files (out of many test files), let's decided on either including all test files (via manifest) or not. I think we shouldn't include test files, what do you think @wouterdebie ?

items.title: Snakebite count has unexpected behavior
items.body:
The file size is listed after replication in snakebite count, but before replication using hdfs count.

snakebite du -s and hdfs' du -s lists it before replication.

items.title: client.text only accepts type str, not unicode
items.body:
Modern linux distributions allow for unicode paths, but there is strict type checking in the Client.test method for only str type paths.  This gives errors when you have utf-8 encoded paths.

It also gives errors when you are using helper classes for path manipulation like path.py, which subclasses 'unicode' (for the above reason).

items.title: Requirements file for both setup and dev
items.body: We now have requirements in both requirements.txt and setup.py, reduce duplication by reading requirements from the file in setup.py, add requirements-dev.txt for development/build/test requirements, make sure to include it in setup.py test/build tasks.

items.title: Add tox for local/automated testing
items.body:
Makes local/automated testing simpler and also reduce duplication  - local virtualenvs and travis setups.

Goals:
- make local testing isolated by default
- reduce duplication of logic - everything in tox setup
- automate local testing (env variable etc)

items.title: 2.4.1 tag is missing
items.body: It would be really great if you could tag 2.4.1 so that we can download the tarball directly from github.

items.title: Kerberos support
items.body:
Hi, 

I'd like to implement Kerberos support for snakebite. Been looking through documentation, but since I don't know snakebite codebase that well, could you point me in the right direction - where should this additional auth be implemented?

Or perhaps there is already some effort at implementing this feature?

items.title: Snakebite on EMR?
items.body: This might be a basic question, but has anyone gotten snakebite working on AWS EMR?

items.title: df misses human readable option
items.body: The df command should accept the -h flag for printing human readable numbers. Compare df(1).

items.title: Client.text() throws inconsistent exception
items.body:
Receiving an inconsistent `Exception: Feailure to read block XXX...XXX` when using client.text([paths])

When `paths` is a list of part files and I'm trying to generate the text, I receive an inconsistent exception where the block its failing to read from changes, and even sometimes generating the text just works.

Code snippet I'm trying to run:

```
part_files = []
for f in sb_conn.ls([path]):
    # FIXME: this is ugly, there must be a better way to do this
    if f['path'].split('/')[-1].startswith('part'):
        part_files.append(f['path'])

# THIS IS WHERE EXCEPTION GETS THROWN
for part in sb_conn.text(part_files):
    gz_tempfile.write(part)
```

My best guess is this has to do with an unstable DataXceiverChannel, but can use some guidance.

items.title: Exceptions in CallMethod don't preserve the original stack trace
items.body:
To preserve the original stack trace, these should just be calling `raise` instead of `raise e`:

https://github.com/spotify/snakebite/blob/master/snakebite/channel.py#L402-L406

items.title: Have client.py read hadoop config
items.body: Right now, Client is initialized with hostname, port and possibly a version number. Maybe it would be nice to have an "autoconfig" client that reads the hadoop config (if HADOOP_HOME is set), just like the command line interface does.

items.title: Successful snakebite mv says OK then ERROR
items.body:

```
uldis@box:~$ sudo -u username snakebite mv /log/logname/2013-10-22.bak /log/logname/2013-10-22.bak_
OK: /log/logname/2013-10-22.bak
ERROR: /log/logname/2013-10-22.bak_ (reason: )
```

```
DEBUG:snakebite.channel:Reset buffer to pos 0

uldis@box:~$ snakebite ls /log/logname
...

uldis@box:~$ snakebite ls /log
...
drwxr-xr-x   - username supergroup                      0 2013-10-24 08:33 /log/logname
...
```

items.title: Client.cat returns a generator that yields a generator that yields strings
items.body:
Is this the intended behavior?  The docs make it sound like Client.cat should return a generator that yields strings.

``` python
a = hdfs_client.cat(['/path/to/my/file'])
a.next()
# prints: <generator object _handle_cat at 0x10535c4b0>
```

while

``` python
a = hdfs_client.cat(['/path/to/my/file'])
a.next().next()
# prints data from the file
```

items.title: Globbing in snakebite leads to not returning proper directories
items.body:
If you have a case where you do:
snakebite ls a/_/b/
then you do not get any results. bizarrely, if you do
snakebite ls a/_/b
you get results
but if you do
snakebite ls a/_/b/c
or
snakebite ls a/_/b/c/
you don't get results

items.title: Support hdfs:// uris
items.body:
Could be nice if `snakebite ls` supported parsing HDFS URIs like hdfs://namenodehost:54310/path/to/dir etc. like hadoop fs -ls does.
Right now it prepends the path with my user dir instead, i.e. it looks for /user/freider/hdfs://namenodehost: ... etc.

items.title: Error running snakebite
items.body:
Hi, I've got the following problem with snakebite:

``` shell
# bin/snakebite 
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "bin/snakebite", line 24, in <module>
    from snakebite.client import Client
  File "/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/snakebite-1.0-py2.6.egg/snakebite/client.py", line 16, in <module>
    import snakebite.protobuf.ClientNamenodeProtocol_pb2 as client_proto
  File "/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/snakebite-1.0-py2.6.egg/snakebite/protobuf/ClientNamenodeProtocol_pb2.py", line 12, in <module>
    import hdfs_pb2
  File "/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/snakebite-1.0-py2.6.egg/snakebite/protobuf/hdfs_pb2.py", line 1687, in <module>
    DESCRIPTOR.message_types_by_name['ExtendedBlockProto'] = _EXTENDEDBLOCKPROTO
AttributeError: 'FileDescriptor' object has no attribute 'message_types_by_name'
```

I've found an issue with similar problem: https://github.com/silverchris/Android-Munin-Node/issues/1 but doing as state there doesn't solve my problem.

I'm running CDH 4.1.2

items.title: Space in filename breaks snakebite ls autocomplete
items.body:
If I have a file "foo bar" in my home dir, and do `snakebite ls` <TAB> <TAB>, the homedir will not be auto-filled and I will be presented all files in my home dir as well as:
/user/freider/foo
and
hopp (just hopp, not /user/freider/hopp)

items.title: mkdir doesn't create parent directories
items.body:
snakebite mkdir /foo/bar/ will not create bar if /foo doesn't exist
"reason: Parent directory doesn't exist:"

Doesn't work with --recurse either.
hadoop fs -mkdir (without flags) does it by default, so I think it would be nice if snakebite also supported it (with or without flag)

items.title: snakebite rmdir doesn't work
Use Travis CI to automatically run tests
Not everything needs to be a generator
items.body:
Making the commands return generators is really useful in many cases, but some commands make a lot more sense to just return one item. A good example are atomic commands like mkdir, as well as a command like serverdefaults().

IMHO in cases where only one output is expected it should return that thing instead of a generator of one item

items.title: touchz doesn't work
items.body:
$ snakebite touchz /user/jco/heyyo
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/bin/snakebite", line 345, in <module>
    cliclient.execute()
  File "/usr/bin/snakebite", line 176, in execute
    return Commands.methods[self.cmd]['method'](self)
  File "/usr/bin/snakebite", line 288, in touchz
    for line in format_results(result, json_output=self.opts.json):
  File "/usr/lib/python2.6/dist-packages/snakebite/formatter.py", line 134, in format_results
    for r in results:
  File "/usr/lib/python2.6/dist-packages/snakebite/client.py", line 438, in touchz
    replication = defaults['replication']
TypeError: 'generator' object is unsubscriptable

items.title: mv command doesn't assume the file is in your user directory
items.body:
snakebite mv /user/name/file /user/name/file2 works, but
snakebite mv file file2 doesn't work
